description:
it starts.
it calculates things.
what more do you want?

sudo apt install gnome-calculator -y
sudo snap remove gnome-calculator
# and you now have a working calculator that loads fast.
summary: All the text comes up in squares so you can't actually use it

description: Otherwise calculation functionality works. The history feature is very nice, easy to click on past calculations the input or output and have that become the current input.

This calculator lags. It takes rougly 2 or 3 seconds to start on a fresh Ubuntu 18.04 install running a gen8 i7 on 32GB ram. The computer uses an SSD and so this must be caused by the calculator software, not the hardware/Ubuntu system (it might of course be an issue relating to gnome which is obviously part of Ubuntu...). I am finding an alternative to this calculator.
summary: A useful calculator except for the performance issues

description: Unfortunately the app doesn't have a background or other window elements, and only displays white numbers - which doesn't work if overlaying a mainly white browser window for example. A bug I suppose, but one that renders it useless.
summary: Could be decent, but not functional without window

Tried using this snap package on Ubuntu 18.10 but the GUI malfunctions - stops taking input from mouse clicking the software buttons for numbers and operators.

This persisted even after a clean reboot of the system.

I uninstalled this snap package and went and installed gnome calculator the old fashioned way:

sudo apt install gnome-calculator

Now the GUI of the calculator functions correctly.
